Posts.Content: hollybee wrote: Hi everyone - just want to say thanks again for all the great help you gave me in the last couple months, and to let you know that I've actually been able to get away with merely bandaging about 4 nights a week along with the MLD. Have been going round and round for 2 months with the therapist/medical supplies dept at our clinic trying to get me a final fit in a sleeve and glove, and we just now got it right! So I haven't even been in a day sleeve for the past 2 months, which tells me that it might not be that critical to wear one - very gratifying. Will keep a close eye on that arm, however. I am so very happy I don't have to spend hours and hours on this business! Hope it stays that way! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: reporting back and thanx hollybee inspiewriter

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2008 08:00PM hollybee wrote: Hi geebung - Do you mind one more post?  It's hopeful news, so read on.  I haven't been on this site for months, and haven't checked your old posts, but it sounds like you have about the same condition I have.  I had bilateral mastectomy (but with right full axillary lymph node dissection) in May 2005.  Didn't have any LE for a year, then I noticed a little swelling in my right forearm.  I kind of panicked and on my onc's advice went to phys therapy and had it bound up for a couple weeks by the LE therapists.  Did more research at the LE network website, and all of their warnings scared me!  Was using night bandages and a day sleeve and glove at that point, and doing massage and exercises.  Then someone on this forum said they were going without their day sleeve because they didn't think it made any difference.  Hmmm!  Was it possible I could do a little less?  So I decided to watch my arm and see if I could back off of anything a little (since it was all such a time-consuming nuisance!).  And after some experimentation, by now I haven't been wearing the day sleeve for probably a year, and at night I massage and wrap maybe 4 nights a week, then lie in bed and do a few exercises with my arm up in the air while I'm reading a book.  Also have had no problem doing some weight-lifting with hand weights every other day (5 to 8 pounds depending on the exercise).  And I've gardened a lot in the summer in short sleeves and haven't had trouble with the sun.  So, really, if it is mild I think we can get away with a lot, even though I believe yes, we will have it forever.  I do keep a close eye on it, and if it seems to be swelling a little more I add another night of wrapping to make sure my arm stays soft and flat and under control.  Also I don't get blood draws in my right arm and I take care of any cuts or abrasions.  Other than that, nada!  So maybe you can do some careful experimenting as well. Can't give you any advice on your proposed surgery, I don't know about that. I love your sweet puppy picture! Holly
Posts.Title: Early stage LE - for life? geebung geebung

Posts.Content: hollybee wrote: Hi - Awhile back, I had asked about whether anybody else got itching after bandaging---because I certainly did. Well, guess what? I quit using any form of lotion or anything else on my skin, and the itching actually stopped! Wonder if the lotion, which we are advised to use, was the culprit? Just thought I would mention this in case someone wants to try it! Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: hollybee wrote: OK, can I get some more help from my friends here? Just finished my 2 wks of therapy with 24/7 bandaging, and my (outer brown) bandages are not so clean anymore. I let them soak in dish detergent and hung them up to dry, but they still don't look terribly clean. Also very wrinkled and I tried ironing them, which helped, but I don't know whether I should be doing that. They are easier to wrap when not wrinkled, for sure. I'm sure you guys are way ahead of me on this. What is the best way to wash so they get clean, and to smooth out? Also, as an aside, how often do you need to buy new ones? And how often do you need to buy the white cottony fluffy stuff you wrap underneath? Thanks again Holly Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2010 01:47AM hollybee wrote: Hi spriest - I'd strongly request your surgeon do a biopsy, or else go seek another surgeon.  I had the same exact thing happen.  I had thought maybe it was due to a slight injury I had had a few months prior, so I put off going to the doctor.  After it didn't go away but got worse, I went to my OB-GYN & he thought it was worth checking.  Mammogram showed nothing, US showed "sort of" something, but unclear.  So he referred me to a surgeon, who said he'd like to biopsy.  Which he did, and it turned out I had invasive lobular breast cancer -- which spreads in a tentacle fashion - - hence the thickening and no noticeable "lump."  This type of cancer occurs in maybe 20% of women with breast cancer, if I remember right.  I too had fibrous breasts.  Guess lobular is notorious for not showing up well on imaging.  I don't understand why your surgeon did not want to biopsy (otherwise how would all these women find out they have lobular cancer if they weren't biopsied?).  I think my surgeon had a very good idea of what it was, and just opened me up where we felt the thickening.  And there it was.  Not to scare you, but please pursue it.  Maybe it could be some other condition, but you need to find out for sure. Hope this helps.  This happened to me in 2005, and I had a mastectomy because the cancer was fairly large, plus the surgeon recommended doing the other breast too because this kind tends more to come back in the other breast.  Am happy with that decision and doing very well since then, by the way.  Lymph nodes were clear too.  YESSS!!!
Posts.Title: Thickening/solidifying but spreading spriest SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2010 12:40AM hollybee wrote: Hi again spriest -  I'm glad you are continuing to try to find out about this.  On the 29th, along with any other questions you had in mind, I'd ask some very pointed questions about the possibility of lobular cancer, and ruling it out via biopsy.  But being in the military, are you totally restricted to military doctors?  I don't know where you are stationed---hopefully in an area with decent medical care---but surely you could visit a general surgeon in the community if you really felt you needed to, right?  I would do so if you are uncomfortable with the advice (or lack of it) that you are receiving from your own doctors --- certainly it will be worth the expense, if something was to be found.  I'm no doctor, but I do think your symptoms are concerning enough to warrant better answers than you are getting. I forgot to mention that my biopsy wasn't the usual needle biopsy type of thing where they aim it at the lump.  Mine was an excisional biopsy, meaning he took a chunk of tissue out to see what was in it.  If that matters.  Hoping the best for you.  keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Thickening/solidifying but spreading spriest SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2008 11:47PM hollybee wrote: Hello Poovey - I'm so sorry you are having to even think about this kind of surgery.  I'm hoping you've had every possible option presented to you by one or more doctors.  About 20 years ago my sister had bc with mets to the sternum, and since she lived in NY she went to Sloan-Kettering to have it (partially) removed.  I do recall that she had a continual problem with pain for the rest of her life, because of it.  Now that was a long time ago, so maybe the surgery was not as advanced as now, and I don't recall that she had the option of a replacement, and I don't suppose everyone has the same experience, but the pain element is probably worth considering, or at least asking about.  Can radiation not be done instead?  Praying you'll find a good solution... H
